description: Learn pre-algebra—all of the basic arithmetic and geometry skills needed for algebra.
subject: pre-algebra

units.title: Factors and multiples
units.description: Understanding and finding factors and multiples. After these videos, you'll be ready for fractions.

lessonSteps.title: Understanding factor pairs
lessonSteps.description: Use multiplication and an understanding of area to identify factor pairs for 6 and 16.

lessonSteps.title: Factor pairs
lessonSteps.description: Practice finding factor pairs for whole numbers.

lessonSteps.title: Finding factors of a number
lessonSteps.description: Sal finds the factors of 120.

lessonSteps.title: Identify factors
lessonSteps.description: Find all the factors of a number within 100.

lessonSteps.title: Reasoning about factors and multiples
lessonSteps.description: Use the equation 3x5=15 to understand the relationship between factors and multiples.

lessonSteps.title: Finding factors and multiples
lessonSteps.description: Sal uses divisibility rules to determine if numbers are factors of 154 and then finds multiples of 14.

lessonSteps.title: Relate factors and multiples
lessonSteps.description: Demonstrate understanding of factors and multiples.

lessonSteps.title: Identifying multiples
lessonSteps.description: Use skip counting and division to identify multiples of 9.

lessonSteps.title: Identify multiples
lessonSteps.description: Practice using skip counting and division to identify multiples of a given number.

lessonSteps.title: Factors and multiples
lessonSteps.description: Learn about factors and multiples and how they relate to each other.

Prime numbers are numbers that have only 2 factors: 1 and themselves. For example, the first 5 prime numbers are 2, 3, 5, 7, and 11. By contrast, numbers with more than 2 factors are call composite numbers.
lessonSteps.title: Prime numbers

lessonSteps.description: Can you recognize the prime numbers in this group of numbers? Which are prime, composite, or neither?
lessonSteps.title: Recognizing prime and composite numbers

lessonSteps.description: Learn about prime and composite numbers and practice identifying them.
lessonSteps.title: Prime and composite numbers intro

lessonSteps.description: Identify prime numbers less than 100.
lessonSteps.title: Identify prime numbers

lessonSteps.description: Identify composite numbers less than 100.
lessonSteps.title: Identify composite numbers

lessonSteps.description: Practice identifying prime and composite numbers.
lessonSteps.title: Prime and composite numbers

lessonSteps.description: Review prime and composite numbers, and try some practice problems.
lessonSteps.title: Prime and composite numbers review
Prime factorization
lessonSteps.description: This video explains the concept of prime numbers and how to find the prime factorization of a number using a factorization tree. It also shows how to write the prime factorization using exponential notation. A prime number is a number that is only divisible by itself and one.

lessonSteps.title: Prime factorization exercise
lessonSteps.description: Learn to find the prime factorization of any number by breaking it down into its prime factors. Understand the difference between prime and composite numbers. Learn from guided examples of finding the prime factorization of 36, 30, and 73.

lessonSteps.title: Prime factorization
lessonSteps.description: Factor two-digit numbers into their prime factorizations.

lessonSteps.title: Common divisibility examples
lessonSteps.description: Common Divisibility Examples

lessonSteps.title: Factors and multiples: days of the week
lessonSteps.description: Sal uses factors and multiples to figure out days of the week.

lessonSteps.title: Patterns with numbers
lessonSteps.description: Generate terms in a pattern when given a rule.  Identify features of a pattern that are not explicit to the rule itself.

lessonSteps.title: Math patterns: table
lessonSteps.description: Sal explains a pattern with the number of seats at a table.

lessonSteps.title: Math patterns: toothpicks
lessonSteps.description: Sal explores a pattern of creating figures with toothpicks.

lessonSteps.title: Patterns with shapes
lessonSteps.description: Practice identifying features of a pattern with shapes.

lessonSteps.title: Constructing numerical expressions
lessonSteps.description: Sometimes, we don't need to solve an equation right away. Instead, we can use the information in a given word problem to construct a numerical expression that represents the information.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with & without parentheses
lessonSteps.description: Explore the concept of order of operations, emphasizing the importance of parentheses in mathematical expressions.Learn how the placement of parentheses can drastically change the outcome of an expression, highlighting the need to follow the correct sequence: parentheses, multiplication and division, then addition and subtraction.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluate expressions with parentheses
lessonSteps.description: Evaluate multi-step expressions with parentheses.  Place parentheses in an expression to make the expression equivalent to a given number.

lessonSteps.title: Translating expressions with parentheses
lessonSteps.description: Dive into the world of writing mathematical expressions from verbal statements. Understand the importance of parentheses in expressions, and how they can change the meaning of calculations.

lessonSteps.title: Translate expressions with parentheses
lessonSteps.description: Practice using parentheses to change expressions from written form to number form.

lessonSteps.title: Create expressions with parentheses
lessonSteps.description: Practice creating expressions with parentheses from real-world contexts.

lessonSteps.title: Graphing patterns on coordinate plane
lessonSteps.description: Learn about understanding numerical patterns. Explore how to generate a second pattern from a given one by applying a rule, in this case, multiplying by 3 and adding 1. Then, graph the pairs of corresponding terms from both patterns on a coordinate plane.

lessonSteps.title: Interpreting patterns on coordinate plane
lessonSteps.description: Explore the concept of numerical patterns, focusing on how to generate, identify, and graph them on a coordinate plane. Understand the relationship between corresponding terms in two different patterns, and how changes in one pattern affect the other.

lessonSteps.title: Interpreting relationships in ordered pairs
lessonSteps.description: Explore the concept of numerical patterns, focusing on how to generate, identify, and graph these patterns on a coordinate plane. Understand the relationships between corresponding terms in two different patterns and how these relationships can be represented as ordered pairs.

lessonSteps.title: Graphing sequence relationships
lessonSteps.description: Explore the concept of numerical patterns. Understand how to generate two sequences using given rules, identify relationships between corresponding terms, form ordered pairs from these terms, and graph these pairs on a coordinate plane.

lessonSteps.title: Rules that relate 2 variables
lessonSteps.description: Identify the rule that describes the relationship between the x- and y-coordinates in a table or set of coordinates.

lessonSteps.title: Tables from rules that relate 2 variables
lessonSteps.description: Complete a table, identify coordinates, and identify inputs and outputs when given a two-variable rule.

lessonSteps.title: Graphs of rules that relate 2 variables
lessonSteps.description: Complete a table from a given rule. Then, plot points from the table on a coordinate plane.

lessonSteps.title: Extend patterns
lessonSteps.description: Practice using a table to extend addition and subtraction patterns.

lessonSteps.title: Relationships between 2 patterns
lessonSteps.description: Generate patterns using given rules. Identify relationships between terms. Graph ordered pairs consisting of corresponding terms from the patterns.

units.title: Ratios and rates
units.description: Learn all about proportional relationships. How are they connected to ratios and rates? What do their graphs look like? What types of word problems can we solve with proportions?

lessonSteps.title: Intro to ratios
lessonSteps.description: The video explains ratios, which show the relationship between two quantities. Using apples and oranges as an example, it demonstrates how to calculate and reduce ratios (6:9 to 2:3) and how to reverse the ratio (9:6 to 3:2).

lessonSteps.title: Basic ratios
lessonSteps.description: In this video, the instructor explains ratios using three examples: amusement park ride lines, Katie's book collection, and a picture of apples and bananas. Ratios compare two quantities and can be written as "a to b" or "a:b." The video demonstrates how to find and interpret ratios in various situations.

lessonSteps.title: Part:whole ratios
lessonSteps.description: In this video, we explore ratios using apples and oranges. We find the simplified ratio of apples to total fruit (2:5) and learn to represent ratios as fractions (2/5). The fraction indicates that 2/5 of the fruit are apples. Key definitions include ratio, simplified ratio, and fraction notation.

lessonSteps.title: Basic ratios
lessonSteps.description: Represent the ratio between two quantities with numbers and with words.

lessonSteps.title: Ratio review
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to find the ratio between two things given a diagram.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios with tape diagrams
lessonSteps.description: In the video, we explore ratios, which compare two quantities. We learn to find missing values using given ratios and discover equivalent ratios by multiplying or dividing both parts by the same number. Key examples include quilts, paint mixtures, and spells cast by characters.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios with tape diagrams
lessonSteps.description: Use tape diagrams to visualize equivalent ratios and describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent ratio word problems
lessonSteps.description: This video teaches solving ratio word problems, using examples like Yoda Soda for guests, fish ratios in a tank, ice cream sundae ingredients, and dog color ratios at a park. Mastering these techniques helps students tackle real-world math challenges.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent ratios with equal groups
lessonSteps.description: Find ratios from countable diagrams. Simplify the ratios by making equal groups.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios and double number lines
lessonSteps.description: Double number lines are a helpful tool for understanding and solving ratio problems. They visually represent the relationship between two quantities, making it easier to find the cost or amount of a single unit. Examples include calculating the price of avocados, building model trains, and making snowballs.

lessonSteps.title: Create double number lines
lessonSteps.description: Create double numbers lines to interpret ratios.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios with double number lines
lessonSteps.description: Use double number lines to visualize equivalent ratios and describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.

lessonSteps.title: Relate double number lines and ratio tables
lessonSteps.description: Use double number lines to create ratio tables.

lessonSteps.title: Ratio tables
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to fill out tables of equivalent ratios.

lessonSteps.title: Solving ratio problems with tables
lessonSteps.description: Equivalent ratios have the same relationship between their numerators and denominators. To find missing values in tables, maintain the same ratio. Comparing fractions is easier with common numerators or denominators. Constant speed is represented by a constant ratio between distance and time.

lessonSteps.title: Ratio tables
lessonSteps.description: Fill out tables of equivalent ratios, including some decimals.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent ratios
lessonSteps.description: One way to identify equivalent ratios is to determine if you can multiply or divide the corresponding parts of the ratio by the same amount. To do this, look at the two ratios and see if there is a common factor that you can use to scale one ratio to the other. If you can scale one ratio to the other by multiplying or dividing every part of the ratio by the same number, then the two ratios are equivalent.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent ratios: recipe
lessonSteps.description: Adjusting a cake recipe for different guest numbers involves understanding ratios. Halving ingredients for a smaller cake maintains the same ratio, like eggs to flour (4:3). Ratios ensure consistent taste and quality, regardless of cake size.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent ratios
lessonSteps.description: Solve simple problems of finding one or more equivalent ratios.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent ratio word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving ratio word problems like, "If Ben reads 10 pages in 15 minutes, how long does it take him to read 40 pages?"

lessonSteps.title: Understanding equivalent ratios
lessonSteps.description: Sal discusses what it means for two ratios to be equivalent.Comparing ratios is essential for determining equivalent relationships between quantities. By analyzing and simplifying ratios, we can identify if they have the same proportion, helping us make decisions in real-life situations like mixing paint colors or comparing food recipes.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent ratios in the real world
lessonSteps.description: This exercise goes beyond solving for equivalent ratios and gets at what it means for ratios to be equivalent.

lessonSteps.title: Understand equivalent ratios in the real world
lessonSteps.description: This exercise builds an understanding of what it means for ratios to be equivalent or not be equivalent.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios on coordinate plane
lessonSteps.description: Ratios represent the relationship between two quantities and can be visualized on a graph. When the ratio is constant, the points form a straight line, illustrating the connection between the quantities. Examples include bakers using flour, car wash charges, and earnings from shoveling snow.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios on coordinate plane
lessonSteps.description: Make tables of equivalent ratios and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios and measurement
lessonSteps.description: Learn to complete ratio tables and solve unit conversion problems with examples like hours to weeks, yards to miles, millimeters to feet, and dollars per pound to dollars per ounce. Master these techniques to tackle real-world problems with ease.

lessonSteps.title: Ratios and units of measurement
lessonSteps.description: Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units (mostly US customary). Transform units appropriately when multiplying or dividing quantities.

lessonSteps.title: Part to whole ratio word problem using tables
lessonSteps.description: Discover how to solve ratio problems with a real-life example involving indoor and outdoor playtimes. Learn to use ratios to determine the number of indoor and outdoor playtimes in a class with a 2:3 ratio and 30 total playtimes.

lessonSteps.title: Part-part-whole ratios
lessonSteps.description: Use a ratio of parts and a total to find the quantities of individual parts.

Rates are essential in understanding everyday situations, such as speed, wages, and food consumption. They help us measure and compare quantities, like miles per hour or calories per serving. Rates are closely related to ratios and play a significant role in math subjects like algebra and calculus, making them crucial for problem-solving and analysis.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to rates

lessonSteps.description: Jayda delivers newspapers on her paper route, taking 3 hours to distribute 189 newspapers. To calculate her rate per hour, divide the total newspapers (189) by the hours taken (3). This results in Jayda delivering 63 newspapers per hour, showcasing her efficiency and speed.
lessonSteps.title: Solving unit rate problem

lessonSteps.description: Nierria earns $75 for tutoring 4 hours. To find her hourly rate, we divide her total earnings by the number of hours worked. By calculating 75 divided by 4, we discover that Nierria makes $18.75 per hour for her tutoring services.
lessonSteps.title: Solving unit price problem

lessonSteps.description: Find the unit rate for two quantities. For example, if you spend 70 dollars on 8 movie tickets, how much does one movie ticket cost?
lessonSteps.title: Unit rates

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn to find unit rates and use them to solve problems. We first calculate the rate for one unit, like cars washed per day or cost per battery. Then, we multiply the unit rate by the desired quantity to find the answer. This method simplifies complex problems and helps us understand real-world situations.
lessonSteps.title: Rate problems

lessonSteps.description: Use rates to solve word problems. For example, Charlie can type 675 words in 9 minutes. How many words can Charlie type in 13 minutes?
lessonSteps.title: Rate problems

lessonSteps.description: A conservationist thinks that squirrels exhibit higher aggression rates when crowded together. To test this, they compare three parks with different squirrel populations and areas. By calculating squirrels per hectare, they find Park C to be the most crowded, followed by Park B and Park A. The conservationist expects the highest aggression rate in Park C due to its crowdedness.
lessonSteps.title: Comparing rates example

lessonSteps.description: Use unit rates to decide, for example, which store has the lowest price per pencil.
lessonSteps.title: Comparing rates

lessonSteps.description: Review the basics of rates and try some practice problems.
lessonSteps.title: Rate review

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn about percentages by shading 20% of a square. The square is divided into 100 smaller squares in a 10x10 grid. To represent 20%, we shade 20 of these smaller squares, which can be done by coloring two rows of 10 squares each. This visual approach helps us understand the concept of percentages.
lessonSteps.title: The meaning of percent

lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learn how to represent 109% using shading. We discover that 109% is equivalent to 109 per 100, or 109/100 as a fraction. By shading a complete 10x10 square and an additional 9 squares, we visually demonstrate 109% of a whole square.
lessonSteps.title: Meaning of 109%

lessonSteps.description: Use hundreds grids to identify percents.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to percents

lessonSteps.description: Converting fractions to percentages is a valuable skill in math. To do this, rewrite the fraction with a denominator of 100, as "percent" means "per 100." For example, 7/10 equals 70/100, or 70%. Additionally, you can add percentages together, such as 100% + 80% = 180%.
lessonSteps.title: Percents from fraction models

lessonSteps.description: Identify percents from fraction models.
lessonSteps.title: Percents from fraction models

lessonSteps.description: In this math problem, we determine the percentage of students taking the bus to school in a class of 28. By using a double number line, we find that 21 out of 28 students take the bus, which is 3/4 of the class. Converting this fraction to a percentage, we discover that 75% of the students ride the bus to school.
lessonSteps.title: Finding percentages with a double number line

lessonSteps.description: Keisha can run 170 meters in one minute today, which is 125% of her distance from three years ago. To find her previous distance, we convert 125% to 5/4 and divide 170 by 5, obtaining 34 meters per fourth. Multiplying 34 by 4 reveals that Keisha could run 136 meters in one minute three years ago.
lessonSteps.title: Finding the whole with a tape diagram

lessonSteps.description: Use double number lines and tape diagrams to find missing parts, wholes, and percentages.
lessonSteps.title: Find percents visually
Fraction, decimal, and percent from visual model
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to convert shaded parts of a square into fractions, decimals, and percentages with ease. Master the skill of representing parts of a whole in different formats, such as simplifying fractions, converting decimals to percentages, and understanding the relationship between them. Boost your math skills and gain confidence in solving real-world problems.

lessonSteps.title: Converting percents to decimals & fractions example
lessonSteps.description: Converting percentages to decimals and fractions is a fundamental math skill. To convert 18% into a decimal, simply divide by 100, resulting in 0.18. To express it as a simplified fraction, find the greatest common factor, which in this case is 2, and divide both the numerator and denominator by it, giving us 9/50.

lessonSteps.title: Percent of a whole number
lessonSteps.description: Discover how to calculate percentages with a simple example: finding 30% of 6. Learn two methods, using fractions and decimals, to solve this problem. Both approaches lead to the same result, showing that 30% of 6 equals 1.8. Master these techniques for everyday calculations.

lessonSteps.title: Ways to rewrite a percentage
lessonSteps.description: Discover how to calculate 2% of 90 using various methods, such as converting percentages to fractions and decimals. Learn to identify correct expressions, like 0.02 times 90 and 2/100 times 90, while eliminating incorrect options. Master percentage calculations with ease and confidence.

lessonSteps.title: Converting between percents, fractions, & decimals
lessonSteps.description: For example, learn how 50%, 1/2, and 0.5 are all equivalent.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent representations of percent problems
lessonSteps.description: Identify expressions that can be used to solve percent problems, like 'What is 5% of 35?'.

lessonSteps.title: Finding common percentages
lessonSteps.description: Calculating percentages in your head is a valuable skill. Common percentages like 1%, 10%, 20%, 25%, 50%, and 400% can be easily converted into fractions (e.g., 1% = 1/100, 10% = 1/10). To find the percentage of a number, simply multiply or divide by the corresponding fraction, making mental math quick and efficient.

lessonSteps.title: Benchmark percents
lessonSteps.description: Find common percentages (1%, 10%, 20%, 25%, 50%, and multiples of 100%) of whole numbers.

lessonSteps.title: Converting percents and fractions review
lessonSteps.description: Review writing percents as fractions and fractions as percents.  Then, try some practice problems.

lessonSteps.title: Converting decimals and percents review
lessonSteps.description: Review writing decimals as percents and percents as decimals.  Then, try some practice problems.

Discover how to calculate percentages with this simple method. First, write the problem as a fraction, then simplify it. Next, convert the fraction to a percentage by making the denominator 100. Alternatively, divide the numbers to get a decimal and multiply by 100 to find the percentage. Master this skill for everyday use.
lessonSteps.title: Finding a percent

lessonSteps.description: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100; solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
lessonSteps.title: Finding percents

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn how to calculate the percentage of recycled cans. Given that 13 out of 20 cans are recycled, we divide 13 by 20 to get 0.65 as a decimal. Multiplying by 100, we find that 65% of cans are recycled, promoting eco-friendly practices and waste reduction.
lessonSteps.title: Percent word problem: recycling cans

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving word problems involving percents.
lessonSteps.title: Percent word problems

units.title: Exponents intro and order of operations

lessonSteps.title: Intro to exponents
lessonSteps.description: Exponents represent repeated multiplication, making numbers grow quickly. For example, 2 to the 3rd power means multiplying three 2's together, resulting in 8. This concept differs from multiplication, which is simply repeated addition. Understanding exponents is essential for mastering higher-level math.

lessonSteps.title: Squaring numbers
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to square basic numbers and make a connection between squaring and the area of a square.

lessonSteps.title: Intro to exponents
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to use exponents and bases. For example, writing 4 x 4 x 4 x 4 x 4 with an exponent.

lessonSteps.title: Meaning of exponents
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing expressions to show what exponents represent.
​Practice taking positive whole-number exponents of non-negative whole numbers.
lessonSteps.title: Powers of whole numbers

lessonSteps.description: Sal Khan considers two different ways to think about why a number raised to the zero power equals one: 1) if 2^3 = 1x2x2x2, then 2^0 = 1 times zero twos, which equals 1. 2) By following a pattern of decreasing an exponent by one by dividing by the base, we find that when we get to the 0 power, we end up dividing the base by itself, resulting in 1.
lessonSteps.title: The zeroth power

lessonSteps.description: Exponents of decimals can be calculated by multiplying the decimal number by itself as many times as the exponent indicates. When multiplying decimals, count the total number of digits to the right of the decimal points in both numbers and place the same number of digits to the right of the decimal point in the product.
lessonSteps.title: Exponents of decimals

lessonSteps.description: Raising fractions to a power is a fundamental math skill. To do this, simply multiply the numerators and denominators separately. For example, when raising a fraction like 2/3 to the third power, multiply the numerators (2 × 2 × 2 = 8) and the denominators (3 × 3 × 3 = 27) to get the result 8/27. This method applies to all powers, making it easy to understand and apply.
lessonSteps.title: Powers of fractions

lessonSteps.description: Practice taking positive whole-number powers of fractions and decimals.
lessonSteps.title: Powers of fractions & decimals

lessonSteps.description: Review the basics of exponents and try some practice problems.
lessonSteps.title: Exponents review

lessonSteps.description: The order of operations is a crucial math concept that ensures consistent results when solving problems with multiple operations. By following PEMDAS (Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division, and Addition and Subtraction), students can accurately evaluate expressions and avoid common mistakes. Mastering this skill is essential for success in mathematics.
lessonSteps.title: Order of operations introduction

lessonSteps.description: The order of operations (PEMDAS) is essential for solving complex math problems. PEMDAS stands for Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division (same level), and Addition and Subtraction (same level). By following these steps, you can simplify and accurately solve mathematical expressions, ensuring a correct final answer.
lessonSteps.title: Worked example: Order of operations (PEMDAS)

lessonSteps.description: Practice evaluating expressions with multiple operations (not including exponents).
lessonSteps.title: Order of operations (no exponents)
Order of operations examples: exponents
lessonSteps.description: The order of operations (PEMDAS) is essential for solving math expressions correctly. By following Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division, and Addition/Subtraction, you ensure accurate results. Understanding the impact of parentheses on calculations helps avoid common mistakes and enhances problem-solving skills.

lessonSteps.title: Comparing exponent expressions
lessonSteps.description: In this math activity, we arrange three math expressions from smallest to largest. We evaluate the expressions: 2 cubed minus 2, 2 squared plus 3 to the power of 0, and 3 squared. We find their values to be 6, 5, and 9. The correct order is 5, 6, and 9.

lessonSteps.title: Order of operations
lessonSteps.description: Practice evaluating expressions using the order of operations.

lessonSteps.title: Order of operations example: fractions and exponents
lessonSteps.description: The order of operations is essential for accurately evaluating complex math expressions. By following the steps of parentheses, exponents, multiplication and division, and finally addition and subtraction, you can simplify expressions and find the correct answer. Mastering these steps ensures a strong foundation in mathematics.

lessonSteps.title: Order of operations with fractions and exponents
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving more challenging problems using the order of operations where exponents and fractions are involved.

lessonSteps.title: Order of operations review
lessonSteps.description: The order of operations are a set of rules for how to evaluate expressions. They make sure everyone gets to the same answer. Many people memorize the order of operations as PEMDAS (parentheses, exponents, multiplication/division, and addition/subtraction).

lessonSteps.title: What is a variable?
lessonSteps.description: Variables in math are symbols, often letters, that represent different values in various situations. They help us understand and solve problems with changing values. For example, when calculating total earnings at a job with an hourly wage plus tips, a variable can represent the fluctuating tips, making it easier to determine total income.

lessonSteps.title: Terms, factors, & coefficients
lessonSteps.description: In math expressions, terms are the components added or subtracted, factors are the elements multiplied within each term, and coefficients are the numbers multiplying variables. Understanding these concepts is crucial for effective communication and problem-solving in mathematics.

lessonSteps.title: Parts of algebraic expressions
lessonSteps.description: Practice identifying the following parts of algebraic expressions: sum, product, quotient, coefficient, factor, term, and variable.

lessonSteps.title: Why aren't we using the multiplication sign?
lessonSteps.description: In algebra, representing multiplication with variables can be tricky due to the similarity between the variable "x" and the multiplication symbol. To avoid confusion, use alternative methods like 2⋅x, 2(x), or 2x. Practice evaluating expressions by substituting given values for variables and following the order of operations.

lessonSteps.title: Terms, factors, and coefficients review
lessonSteps.description: Review terms, factors, and coefficients, and try some practice problems.

In this math lesson, we explore the expression 5 t plus 3 to calculate the cost of participating in a hospital raffle fundraiser. By evaluating the expression for different values of t, the number of tickets purchased, we find the costs for buying 1, 8, and 10 tickets, which are 8, 43, and 53 dollars, respectively.
lessonSteps.title: Evaluating an expression with one variable

lessonSteps.description: Substitute a whole number into an expression with 1 or 2 operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), and evaluate.
lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with one variable

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn to evaluate expressions with exponents and variables. We practice substituting values for variables and calculating the results. By mastering this skill, we can solve problems involving exponential expressions, enhancing our understanding of algebra and mathematical concepts.
lessonSteps.title: Evaluating exponent expressions with variables

lessonSteps.description: Evaluating expressions with exponents involves substituting a given value for the variable and following the order of operations. Calculate the exponent first, then perform any multiplication or division. Mastering this skill is essential for solving more complex algebraic problems and understanding mathematical relationships.
lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions like 5x² & ⅓(6)ˣ

lessonSteps.description: Practice evaluating expressions with exponents by substituting values for the variables.
lessonSteps.title: Variable expressions with exponents

lessonSteps.description: A mixture of explanations, examples, and practice problems to have you evaluating expressions with one variable in no time!
lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with one variable
Evaluating expressions with two variables
lessonSteps.description: Evaluating expressions with multiple variables involves substituting given values for each variable and simplifying the expression. By replacing variables with their corresponding values, we can easily compute the result of expressions, even for more complex examples with multiple terms and operations.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with multiple variables
lessonSteps.description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with two variables: fractions & decimals
lessonSteps.description: Evaluating expressions with two variables involves substituting the given values for each variable and simplifying the expression. By practicing with examples, we can improve our skills in solving these types of problems, ultimately enhancing our understanding of algebraic expressions and their real-world applications.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with multiple variables: fractions & decimals
lessonSteps.description: Practice evaluating expressions in two variables by plugging in values for the variables. These problems include some fractions and decimals.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with two variables
lessonSteps.description: We've already evaluated expressions with one variable. Now it's time to do it with two variables.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with two variables: fractions & decimals
lessonSteps.description: We've already evaluated expressions with two variables. Now it's time to do it with fractions and decimals.

lessonSteps.title: Expression value intuition
lessonSteps.description: Discover how expressions change as variables within them shift. Learn that increasing x in "100 - x" results in a decreasing value, while decreasing x in "5/x + 5" (x remaining positive) leads to an increase. Observe that "3y/2y" stays constant as y increases, maintaining a value of 3/2.

lessonSteps.title: Expression value intuition
lessonSteps.description: In an expression like 2x+7, the value of x can change. As the variable increases and decreases, what happens to the value of the expression?

lessonSteps.title: Expression value intuition
lessonSteps.description: Practice thinking about how the values of expressions change as the values of their variables change.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with variables: temperature
lessonSteps.description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with variables word problems
lessonSteps.description: Learn to evaluate expressions in word problems to gain new information.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with variables word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice plugging in values to evaluate real-world algebraic expressions. These are introductory problems, so the expressions aren't too complicated.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with variables: cubes
lessonSteps.description: Discover how to calculate the total surface area of cube-shaped containers with varying side lengths. Learn the formula 6x², where x represents the side length of a cube. Apply this formula to find the surface area of multiple cubes, and add the results to determine the combined surface area that needs painting.

lessonSteps.title: Evaluating expressions with variables: exponents
lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn to evaluate an algebraic expression with exponents by following the order of operations (PEMDAS). We substitute a given value for the variable, calculate exponents, perform multiplication, and finally, subtraction. By applying these steps, we successfully find the value of the expression.

lessonSteps.title: Writing basic expressions with variables
lessonSteps.description: Learn to write expressions with variables in math! Discover how to represent various operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division using variables. Master the art of creating expressions for real-life situations, such as finding the sum of two numbers or the difference between two values. Boost your algebra skills and become a pro at handling variables!

lessonSteps.title: Writing algebraic subtraction expressions
lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learned how to turn word statements into algebraic expressions. We practiced with examples like "two less than x" and "y fewer than three." Understanding how to translate words into math helps us solve real-life problems and makes algebra more fun!

lessonSteps.title: Writing basic expressions with variables
lessonSteps.description: Learn to write expressions for phrases like "3 more than x."

lessonSteps.title: Writing basic expressions with variables
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing basic algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.

lessonSteps.title: Writing expressions with variables
lessonSteps.description:
To write simple algebraic expressions from mathematical statements, you can follow this procedure: 1. Identify the key terms in the written statement (e.g. "sum," "product," "quantity"). 2. Break the statement down into its component parts. 3. Translate each part into algebraic form, using the appropriate symbols and operations. 
4. Simplify the expression if needed.

lessonSteps.title: Writing expressions with parentheses
lessonSteps.description: In math, using parentheses helps follow the correct order of operations. When multiplying a number by the sum or difference of two terms, like 5 times (x-2) or 10 times (y+3), parentheses ensure the addition or subtraction happens first. This avoids confusion and ensures accurate results.

lessonSteps.title: Writing expressions with variables & parentheses
lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learned about expressions and how to simplify them step by step. We explored adding and multiplying expressions, like negative numbers and variables. By practicing these skills, we can solve more complex algebra problems with ease and confidence.

lessonSteps.title: Writing expressions with variables
lessonSteps.description: Learn to write expressions for more challenging phrases like "8 less than the product of 7 and x."

lessonSteps.title: Writing expressions with variables
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing algebraic expressions to match verbal descriptions of mathematical operations.

lessons.title: Writing basic algebraic expressions word problems

lessonSteps.description: Susie runs a race at 5 miles per hour for t hours. To find the distance, multiply her speed by time (5t). In a poker game, winnings are split among p players, so each gets $548/p. Phil's net winnings are x dollars minus the $100 entry fee. Hillary makes 48 chocolate chip cookies and y sugar cookies, totaling 48+y cookies.
lessonSteps.title: Writing basic expressions word problems

lessonSteps.description: Learn to write expressions to model word problems. For example, "Ben has b dollars, and Cam has 7 fewer dollars than Ben."
lessonSteps.title: Writing basic expressions word problems

lessonSteps.description: Practice writing basic algebraic expressions to model real-world situations.
lessonSteps.title: Writing basic expressions word problems

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to apply the distributive law of multiplication over addition and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive law or the distributive property.
lessonSteps.title: Distributive property over addition

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to apply the distributive property of multiplication over subtraction and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive property or distributive law.
lessonSteps.title: Distributive property over subtraction

lessonSteps.description: To apply the distributive property to an algebraic expression, you multiply each term inside the parentheses by the number or variable outside the parentheses. For example, to simplify 2(x + 3), you would multiply 2 by both x and 3, resulting in 2x + 6.
lessonSteps.title: Distributive property with variables

lessonSteps.description: Practice applying the distributive property to algebraic expressions.
lessonSteps.title: Distributive property with variables

lessonSteps.description: Use the distributive property to factor out common numerical factors from expressions with variables. Remember, the greatest common factor is not always the only common factor.
lessonSteps.title: Create equivalent expressions by factoring

lessonSteps.description: Practice applying the distributive property to factor algebraic expressions.
lessonSteps.title: Factor with distributive property (variables)
Intro to combining like terms
lessonSteps.description: Adding like terms is a fundamental concept in algebra. Coefficients are the numbers in front of variables, and they can be added when the variables are the same. For example, 2x + 3x equals 5x. When dealing with different variables, such as x and y, add them separately, resulting in expressions like 5x + 9y.

lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms
lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learned how to add and subtract variables, like apples (a) or x's. We discovered that when we combine or take away the same variable, we can simply count them up or down. For example, 5x minus 2x equals 3x. This helps us understand basic algebra concepts.

lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms example
lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learned how to simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. We focused on understanding the intuition behind adding and subtracting coefficients of the same variables. The result is a simplified expression, making it easier to work with and solve problems.

lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms
lessonSteps.description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms.

In this math lesson, we learn how to find equivalent expressions by combining like terms and factoring. We start with an expression like x + 2 - y + x + 2 and simplify it by adding the x terms and factoring out common factors. This helps us compare expressions and solve problems more easily.
lessonSteps.title: Equivalent expressions

lessonSteps.description: Practice determining whether or not two algebraic expressions are equivalent by manipulating the expressions. These problems require you to combine like terms and apply the distributive property.
lessonSteps.title: Equivalent expressions

units.title: Equations & inequalities introduction
units.description: In this topic, we will look at 1- and 2-step equations, as well as expressions and inequalities.

lessonSteps.title: Variables, expressions, & equations
lessonSteps.description: In algebra, we use variables like x, y, and z to represent unknown values. Expressions are combinations of variables and numbers, while equations equate two expressions. Variables can take on different values depending on the context, and we can evaluate expressions by substituting values for the variables.

lessonSteps.title: Testing solutions to equations
lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn how to solve an equation with one variable. We test different values for x to see which one satisfies the equation. By substituting x with the given options, we find the correct solution that makes both sides of the equation equal. Practice makes perfect!

lessonSteps.title: Intro to equations
lessonSteps.description: Learn what an equation is and what it means to find the solution of an equation.

lessonSteps.title: Testing solutions to equations
lessonSteps.description: Practice plugging in values to equations and checking to see if the equations hold true.

In this fun math problem, we have a balanced scale with a mystery mass on one side and several 1-kilogram masses on the other. To find the mystery mass, we remove the same number of 1-kilogram masses from both sides, keeping the scale balanced. Then, we can easily determine the mystery mass's weight.
lessonSteps.title: Same thing to both sides of equations

lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learn about balancing scales and solving equations. We discover that to find a mystery mass, we can set up an equation using equal signs and balance both sides. By subtracting the same amount from each side, we can solve for the unknown mass, helping us understand the relationship between the two sides of the scale.
lessonSteps.title: Representing a relationship with an equation

lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learn how to find the mass of a mystery object using a balanced scale. By keeping the scale balanced and taking equal portions from both sides, we can determine the mass of the mystery object. This helps us understand the concept of equality in real-life situations.
lessonSteps.title: Dividing both sides of an equation

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn how to solve a balance scale problem with unknown mass. We represent the problem using an algebraic equation, 3x = 9, where x is the unknown mass. By dividing both sides by 3, we find that x = 3, meaning each object has a mass of 3 kilograms.
lessonSteps.title: One-step equations intuition

lessonSteps.description: Identify the equation represented by a tape diagram. Then, solve for the unknown in the equation.
lessonSteps.title: Identify equations from visual models (tape diagrams)

lessonSteps.description: Identify the equation represented by a  hanger diagram. Then, solve for the unknown in the equation.
lessonSteps.title: Identify equations from visual models (hanger diagrams)

lessonSteps.description: Use a visual model of an equation to solve for the unknown in the equation.
lessonSteps.title: Solve equations from visual models

lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learn how to solve simple equations with one unknown variable. To find the unknown, we remove extra numbers by doing the opposite operation on both sides of the equation. This keeps the equation balanced and helps us find the value of the unknown variable.
lessonSteps.title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn to solve simple equations with one variable. We isolate the variable by removing other terms on the same side. For example, if a + 5 = 54, we subtract 5 from both sides to find a = 49. Finally, we check our solution by substituting the value back into the original equation.
lessonSteps.title: One-step addition equation

lessonSteps.description: Learn to solve equations like "x + 3 = 9" or "y  - 5 = 8".
lessonSteps.title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting the same value from both sides.
lessonSteps.title: One-step addition & subtraction equations

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we practice solving equations with variables and fractions. We learn to isolate the variable by adding or subtracting terms from both sides of the equation. This helps us find the value of the variable, making the equation true. Keep practicing and have fun!
lessonSteps.title: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations in one step by adding or subtracting a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.
lessonSteps.title: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals

lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learn how to solve simple algebraic equations systematically. We focus on understanding the meaning of equations, like 7x = 14, and using techniques like dividing both sides of the equation by the coefficient to isolate the variable. This method helps us find the value of the unknown variable, making algebra easier and more approachable.
lessonSteps.title: One-step division equations

lessonSteps.description: In this math lesson, we learn to solve equations with x divided by a number, like x/3 = 14. To find x, we isolate it by multiplying both sides of the equation by the divisor (3). This gives us x = 42. Finally, we check our answer by substituting x back into the original equation to make sure it's correct.
lessonSteps.title: One-step multiplication equations

lessonSteps.description: Learn to solve equations like "4x = 20" or "y/3 = 7".
lessonSteps.title: One-step multiplication & division equations

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a value from both sides.
lessonSteps.title: One-step multiplication & division equations

lessonSteps.description: In this fun math adventure, we tackle equations with fractions and decimals. We learn to balance equations by applying the same operation on both sides, simplifying fractions, and eliminating decimals. It's a step-by-step journey to mastering algebra!
lessonSteps.title: One-step multiplication & division equations: fractions & decimals

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to solve equations with fractions by using reciprocals. Multiply both sides of the equation by the reciprocal of the fraction to make the coefficient one. This simplifies the equation, making it easier to find the value of the variable.
lessonSteps.title: One-step multiplication equations: fractional coefficients

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.
lessonSteps.title: One-step multiplication & division equations: fractions & decimals

lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learned how to spot mistakes in solving algebraic equations. We saw that it's crucial to apply the same operation to both sides of the equation. We also learned the importance of accurate arithmetic in getting the correct answer. Lastly, we saw that not all steps, even if algebraically correct, help simplify the equation.
lessonSteps.title: Finding mistakes in one-step equations

lessonSteps.description: Gain a deeper understanding of solving one-step equations by studying a correct and an incorrect example.
lessonSteps.title: Finding mistakes in one-step equations

lessonSteps.description: Practice spotting the mistake in someone else's work as they attempt to solve one-step equations.
lessonSteps.title: Find the mistake in one-step equations

lessonSteps.description: Anna wants to throw a pizza party for her birthday. She has $42.50 to spend on pizza boxes that cost $8.50 each. To figure out how many pizzas she can buy, she divides the total money by the cost per box. This concept can also be applied to other situations, like a class selling candy boxes for a fundraiser.
lessonSteps.title: Modeling with one-step equations

lessonSteps.description: Write a statement like, '8 more than y is 17' as an equation. Then, solve for the variable.
lessonSteps.title: Translate one-step equations and solve

lessonSteps.description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations.
lessonSteps.title: Model with one-step equations

lessonSteps.description: Practice writing basic equations to model real-world situations. Then solve for the variable.
lessonSteps.title: Model with one-step equations and solve
Testing solutions to inequalities
lessonSteps.description: Inequalities are like puzzles where you compare two things. You can solve these puzzles by trying different numbers and seeing which ones make the puzzle true. Some numbers will work for one puzzle but not for another. It's all about finding the right fit!

lessonSteps.title: Testing solutions to inequalities (basic)
lessonSteps.description: Practice plugging in values to inequalities, like x>5, and checking to see if the inequalities hold true.

lessonSteps.title: Plotting inequalities
lessonSteps.description: To plot an inequality, such as x>3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number (e.g., 3). Then if the sign includes equal to (≥ or ≤), fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <), leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

lessonSteps.title: Plotting an inequality example
lessonSteps.description: Drawing a number line helps visualize 'x is less than 4'. We mark 4 with a circle, not a dot, because 4 isn't included. Then, we color the line below 4, showing all values less than 4. Easy peasy, lemon squeezy

lessonSteps.title: Graphing basic inequalities
lessonSteps.description: Identify graphs of inequalities like x>8 or x<-4.

lessonSteps.title: Inequality from graph
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing equations of inequalities graphed on number lines.

lessonSteps.title: Plotting inequalities
lessonSteps.description: Create  number line graphs of inequalities.

lessonSteps.title: Inequalities word problems
lessonSteps.description: Inequalities are a handy tool for comparing values. For example, if Eric is shorter than Priti who is 158 cm tall, we write E < 158. If Sydney wears skirts when it's warmer than 25 degrees, we say T > 25. If Hayley finishes a race after Lola's 53 seconds, we write H > 53.

lessonSteps.title: Inequalities word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing inequalities with variables to describe real-world situations.

lessonSteps.title: Graphing inequalities review
lessonSteps.description: Review graphing inequalities with variables on number lines, and then try some practice problems.

lessonSteps.title: Dependent & independent variables
lessonSteps.description: We introduce independent and dependent variables: how to identify the independent/dependent variable in a given setting, and how we write equations with the dependent variable by itself.

lessonSteps.title: Independent versus dependent variables
lessonSteps.description: Practice figuring out if a variable is dependent or independent.

lessonSteps.title: Dependent & independent variables: graphing
lessonSteps.description: When you answer math quiz questions, each correct answer earns you 5 points. The number of correct answers (x) and total points (y) are related by the equation y = 5x. This relationship can be visualized on a graph.

lessonSteps.title: Tables from equations with 2 variables
lessonSteps.description: Complete a table and identify coordinates when given a two-variable equation, such as y=2x+4.

lessonSteps.title: Match equations to coordinates on a graph
lessonSteps.description: Identify the coordinates that match a two-variable equation. Also, identify the corresponding equation when given  coordinates.

lessonSteps.title: Dependent and independent variables review
lessonSteps.description: Identify dependent and independent variables and apply them to contexts.

In this lesson, we learn how to write equations representing real-world scenarios. First, we explore how to calculate time taken for a walk based on speed and distance. Then, we discover how to determine the amount of water needed in a soup recipe based on the quantity of vegetable stock. Fun, right?
lessonSteps.title: Writing equations for relationships between quantities

lessonSteps.description: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity in terms of the other quantity.
lessonSteps.title: Relationships between quantities in equations

lessonSteps.description: Rava is studying an electric car. She finds out that the more she charges the car, the further it can go. The relationship is simple and direct: more charging time equals more distance. This helps her predict the car's range based on how long it's been charged.
lessonSteps.title: Analyzing relationships between variables

lessonSteps.description: Practice analyzing the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relating these to the equation.
lessonSteps.title: Analyze relationships between variables
Solving percent problems
lessonSteps.description: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.

lessonSteps.title: Equivalent expressions with percent problems
lessonSteps.description: Create expressions with fractions and decimals to solve real world percent word problems.

lessonSteps.title: Percent word problem: magic club
lessonSteps.description: Sal solves percent word problems including percent comparisons and percent of change.

lessonSteps.title: Percent problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving word problems involving percents, including percents comparisons and percent of change,

lessonSteps.title: Percent word problems: tax and discount
lessonSteps.description: Sal solves percent word problems involving tax, tip, and discounts.

lessonSteps.title: Tax and tip word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving percent word problems involving tax and tip.

lessonSteps.title: Percent word problem: guavas
lessonSteps.description: We're putting a little algebra to work to find the full price when you know the discount price in this percent word problem.

lessonSteps.title: Discount, markup, and commission word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving percent word problems involving price discounts, price markups, and commission fees.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problem: school report
lessonSteps.description: First visualize this word problem then use subtraction and multiplication of decimals and fractions to get at the answer.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problem: cosmetics
lessonSteps.description: Remember units of measurement? Convert minutes into hours and put your knowledge of fractions to work in this word problem.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problem: cab
lessonSteps.description: Budgeting money is one of the most valuable math skills you'll learn. Practice with us as we figure out how much money is left after a cab fare.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problem: ice
lessonSteps.description: Word problems force us to put concepts to work using real-world applications. In this example, determine the volume of frozen water and express the answer as a fraction.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problem: computers
lessonSteps.description: In this word problem, we'll compare the weight of two objects using a ratio of integers. We'll practice simplifying a fraction, too.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problem: stock
lessonSteps.description: Use your knowledge of proportions and fractions to determine shareholders profit in this word problem.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problem: checking account
lessonSteps.description: Your checking account is overdrawn. Not good. Use your knowledge of decimals and adding negative and positive numbers to bring your account back into the black.

lessonSteps.title: Rational number word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving multi-step word problems. The numbers in these problems may be fractions, decimals, and percents.

lessonSteps.title: Rates with fractions
lessonSteps.description: Sal solves an example problem with rates with fractions.

lessonSteps.title: Rates with fractions
lessonSteps.description: Practice computing rates associated with ratios of fractions or decimals.

Proportional relationships are relationships between two variables where their ratios are equivalent. Another way to think about them is that, in a proportional relationship, one variable is always a constant value times the other. That constant is known as the "constant of proportionality".
lessonSteps.title: Introduction to proportional relationships

lessonSteps.description: The video explains the concept of the constant of proportionality in graphs. It shows how to calculate it using the formula Y = KX or Y/X = K, where K is the constant. It also demonstrates how to identify lines with specific constants on a graph.
lessonSteps.title: Identifying constant of proportionality graphically

lessonSteps.description: In this lesson, we learn about the constant of proportionality in a graph. It's the number we multiply by x to get y. In our example, when x increases, y increases three times as much. So, our constant of proportionality is 3.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from graph

lessonSteps.description: Practice identifying the constant of proportionality from graphs.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from graphs

lessonSteps.description: The constant of proportionality is a key concept in math. It's the number that we multiply one variable by to get another in a proportional relationship. This can be seen in everyday situations like cooking or in equations.
lessonSteps.title: Identifying the constant of proportionality from equation

lessonSteps.description: Sal identifies the constant of proportionality from equations.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from equation

lessonSteps.description: Practice identifying the constant of proportionality from equations.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from equations

lessonSteps.description: Identifying proportionality constants by looking at tables of values.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from tables

lessonSteps.description: Practice identifying the constant of proportionality from tables.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from tables

lessonSteps.description: Sal identifies the constant of proportionality from table.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from table (with equations)

lessonSteps.description: Use the equation, y=rx to identify r from a table of values.
lessonSteps.title: Constant of proportionality from tables (with equations)

lessons.title: Compare and interpret constants of proportionality

lessonSteps.title: Comparing constants of proportionality
lessonSteps.description: Working example comparing constants of proportionality.

lessonSteps.title: Comparing proportionality constants
lessonSteps.description: Sal compares constants of proportionality in various forms, such as graphs, equations, contexts, diagrams, and tables.

lessonSteps.title: Compare constants of proportionality
lessonSteps.description: Identify and compare constants of proportionality in graphs, tables, equations, contexts, and diagrams.

lessonSteps.title: Interpret proportionality constants
lessonSteps.description: Sal interpret what the constant of proportionality means in a context.

lessonSteps.title: Interpret constants of proportionality
lessonSteps.description: Interpret the meaning of constants of proportionality in tables, equations, contexts, and diagrams.

lessonSteps.title: Interpret constant of proportionality in graphs
lessonSteps.description: Interpret the meaning of constants of proportionality in graphs.

lessonSteps.title: Intro to proportional relationships
lessonSteps.description: To know if a relationship is proportional, you should look at the ratios between the two variables. If the ratio is always the same, the relationship is proportional. If the ratio changes, the relationship is not proportional.

lessonSteps.title: Proportional relationships: movie tickets
lessonSteps.description: When going to the movies, is the price you pay proportional to the number of tickets you buy?

lessonSteps.title: Proportional relationships: bananas
lessonSteps.description: A proportionality problem about eating bananas.

lessonSteps.title: Proportional relationships: spaghetti
lessonSteps.description: Given a table of ratios, watch as we test them for equivalence and determine whether the relationship is proportional.

lessonSteps.title: Identify proportional relationships
lessonSteps.description: Practice telling whether or not the relationship between two quantities is proportional by looking at a table of the relationship.

lessonSteps.title: Proportional relationships
lessonSteps.description: Sal determines which ratios are proportionate to a ratio provided in a context.

lessonSteps.title: Proportional relationships
lessonSteps.description: Practice telling whether or not the relationship between two quantities is proportional by reasoning about equivalent ratios.

lessonSteps.title: Is side length & area proportional?
lessonSteps.description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and area.

lessonSteps.title: Is side length & perimeter proportional?
lessonSteps.description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and perimeter.
Worked example identifying proportional relationships from graphs
lessonSteps.title: Identifying proportional relationships from graphs

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to tell proportional relationships by drawing graphs. Key idea: the graph of a proportional relationship is a straight line through the origin.
lessonSteps.title: Proportional relationships: graphs

lessonSteps.description: Practice telling whether or not the relationship between two quantities is proportional by looking at a graph of the relationship.
lessonSteps.title: Identify proportional relationships from graphs

lessonSteps.description: Worked example interpreting graphs of proportional relationships
lessonSteps.title: Interpreting graphs of proportional relationships

lessonSteps.description: Practice reading and analyzing graphs of proportional relationships.
lessonSteps.title: Interpreting graphs of proportional relationships
Worked example: Solving proportions
lessonSteps.description: Learn the reasoning behind solving proportions. We'll put some algebra to work to get our answers, too.

lessonSteps.title: Solving proportions
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving basic proportions.

lessonSteps.title: Writing proportions example
lessonSteps.description: Some examples of writing two ratios and setting them equal to each other to solve proportion word problems.

lessonSteps.title: Writing proportions
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing proportions to describe real-world situations.

lessonSteps.title: Proportion word problem: cookies
lessonSteps.description: A recipe for oatmeal cookies calls for 2 cups of flour for every 3 cups of oatmeal. How much flour is needed for a big batch of cookies that uses 9 cups of oatmeal?

lessonSteps.title: Proportion word problem: hot dogs
lessonSteps.description: Mika can eat 21 hot dogs in 66 minutes. She wants to know how many minutes it would take her to eat 35 hot dogs if she can keep up the same pace.

lessonSteps.title: Proportion word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice setting up and solving proportions to solve word problems.

lessonSteps.title: Multi-step ratio and percent problems
lessonSteps.description: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems. Examples include simple interest, tax, markups and markdowns, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

lessonSteps.title: Equations for proportional relationships
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to write a proportional equation y=kx where k is the so-called "constant of proportionality".

lessonSteps.title: Writing proportional equations from tables
lessonSteps.description: Writing an equation to describe the relationship between the number of scoops in an ice cream cone and the price

lessonSteps.title: Writing proportional equations
lessonSteps.description: Sal figures out the constant of proportionality when dealing with a constant rate.

lessonSteps.title: Writing proportional equations
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing equations to describe proportional relationships.

Adding like terms is a fundamental concept in algebra. Coefficients are the numbers in front of variables, and they can be added when the variables are the same. For example, 2x + 3x equals 5x. When dealing with different variables, such as x and y, add them separately, resulting in expressions like 5x + 9y.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to combining like terms

lessonSteps.description: We've learned about order of operations and combining like terms. Let's layer the distributive property on top of this.
lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients & distribution

lessonSteps.description: This example of combining like terms in an expression gets a little hairy. Pay attention.
lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients

lessonSteps.description: Simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. Coefficients on some terms are negative.
lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients

lessonSteps.description: Practice combining like terms using the distributive property. These problems involve adding and subtracting negative numbers.
lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms with negative coefficients & distribution

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to rewrite algebraic expressions by combining like terms. The expressions in this video have decimal and fraction coefficients.
lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms with rational coefficients

lessonSteps.description: Practice combining like terms for expressions that have rational coefficients. This requires adding and subtracting fractions.
lessonSteps.title: Combining like terms with rational coefficients

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to factor out the greatest common factor from an algebraic expression like 2+4x.
lessonSteps.title: The distributive property with variables

lessonSteps.description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).
lessonSteps.title: Factoring with the distributive property

lessonSteps.description: Factor and expand expressions like -3x-9 by applying the distributive property.  Expressions include variables and negative numbers.
lessonSteps.title: Distributive property with variables (negative numbers)

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to identify equivalent expressions using your knowledge of the distributive property and negative numbers.
lessonSteps.title: Equivalent expressions: negative numbers & distribution

lessonSteps.description: Practice figuring out which expressions are equivalent by applying your knowledge of negative numbers and the distributive property.
lessonSteps.title: Equivalent expressions: negative numbers & distribution
Interpreting linear expressions: diamonds
lessonSteps.description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.

lessonSteps.title: Interpreting linear expressions: flowers
lessonSteps.description: Let's practice matching expressions to their meaning in this example of interpreting linear expressions.

lessonSteps.title: Interpreting linear expressions
lessonSteps.description: Practice interpreting linear expressions

lessonSteps.title: Writing expressions word problems
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to write expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

lessonSteps.title: Writing expressions word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing slightly more complex algebraic expressions to model real-world situations.

lessonSteps.title: Same thing to both sides of equations
lessonSteps.description: In this fun math problem, we have a balanced scale with a mystery mass on one side and several 1-kilogram masses on the other. To find the mystery mass, we remove the same number of 1-kilogram masses from both sides, keeping the scale balanced. Then, we can easily determine the mystery mass's weight.

lessonSteps.title: Intro to two-step equations
lessonSteps.description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equations intuition
lessonSteps.description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples, but you can do it!

lessonSteps.title: Worked example: two-step equations
lessonSteps.description: Sal solves the equation -16 = x/4 + 2. It takes two steps because he first has to subtract 2 from both sides and then multiply both sides by 4.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equations
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations that take two steps to solve. For example, solve  -16 = x/4 + 2.

lessons.title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to solve equations that involve decimals and fractions. The equations shown in this video are called "two-step" equations because they each take two steps to solve.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
lessonSteps.description: Let's practice some two step equations, some of which require merging terms and using the distributive property.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equations with decimals and fractions
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations that take two steps to solve. These problems involve arithmetic with fractions and decimals.

lessonSteps.title: Find the mistake: two-step equations
lessonSteps.description: When doing algebra, we sometimes make mistakes! It's important to be able to check our own work (and other people's work) for correctness.

lessonSteps.title: Find the mistake: two-step equations
lessonSteps.description: Practice spotting the mistake in someone else's work as they attempt to solve two-step equations. Common mistakes include distributing incompletely and not performing the same operation on both sides of the equation.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equations review
lessonSteps.description: A two-step equation is an algebraic equation that takes you two steps to solve. You've solved the equation when you get the variable by itself, with no numbers in front of it, on one side of the equal sign.

lessonSteps.title: Equation word problem: super yoga (1 of 2)
lessonSteps.description: Using information from the Super Yoga word problem, explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

lessonSteps.title: Equation word problem: super yoga (2 of 2)
lessonSteps.description: If you're coming to this video before seeing the previous one, back up! Otherwise, we're solving one-step equations to learn which Super Plan is the best value for our budget.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equation word problem: computers
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equation word problem: garden
lessonSteps.description: Here's a nifty word problem in which we find the dimensions of a garden given only the perimeter. Let's create an equation to solve!

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equation word problem: oranges
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to solve a word problem by writing an equation to model the situation. In this video, we use the linear equation 210(t-5) = 41,790.

lessonSteps.title: Interpret two-step equation word problems
lessonSteps.description: Determine what terms and variables in two-step equations represent in a real-world context.

lessonSteps.title: Two-step equations word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice writing equations to model and solve real-world situations.

lessonSteps.title: Testing solutions to inequalities
lessonSteps.description: Inequalities are like puzzles where you compare two things. You can solve these puzzles by trying different numbers and seeing which ones make the puzzle true. Some numbers will work for one puzzle but not for another. It's all about finding the right fit!

lessonSteps.title: Testing solutions to inequalities
lessonSteps.description: Practice plugging in values to inequalities, like 2x<14, and checking to see if the inequalities hold true.

lessonSteps.title: One-step inequalities examples
lessonSteps.description: Our discussion of linear inequalities begins with multiplying and dividing by negative numbers. Pay attention for the word "swap." Super important!

lessonSteps.title: One-step inequalities: -5c ≤ 15
lessonSteps.description: In addition to solving the inequality, we'll graph the solution. Remember to swap if you mutiply both sides of the inequality by a negative number.

lessonSteps.title: One-step inequalities
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving inequalities in one step.

lessonSteps.title: One-step inequality word problem
lessonSteps.description: Inequalities are more than abstract concepts and exercises. They help solve real life problems. Here's an example.

lessonSteps.title: One-step inequalities review
lessonSteps.description: Review evaluating one-step inequalities, and try some practice problems.
Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.
lessonSteps.title: Two-step inequalities

lessonSteps.description: Solve inequalities that take two steps to solve. For example, solve 3x + 2 > 5.
lessonSteps.title: Two-step inequalities

lessonSteps.description: We'll talk you through this fun and challenging inequality problem.
lessonSteps.title: Two-step inequality word problem: apples

lessonSteps.description: Let's tackle this word problem together. We'll interpret the information and then construct a linear inequality to solve it.
lessonSteps.title: Two-step inequality word problem: R&B

lessonSteps.description: Practice constructing, interpreting, and solving linear inequalities that model real-world situations.
lessonSteps.title: Two-step inequality word problems

lessonSteps.description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to square roots

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to find the square root of perfect squares like 25, 36, and 81.
lessonSteps.title: Square roots of perfect squares

lessonSteps.description: Practice finding the square root of a perfect square positive integer.
lessonSteps.title: Square roots

lessonSteps.description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to cube roots

lessonSteps.description: Practice finding the cube root of a perfect cube positive integer.
lessonSteps.title: Cube roots

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to find the cube root of negative 512 by breaking it down into prime factors. When we find groups of three of the same factor, we know that's a factor of the cube root. It helps to remember that -1*-1*-1 is -1, so the cube root of -1 is itself.
lessonSteps.title: Worked example: Cube root of a negative number

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations by squaring or cubing both sides.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with square roots & cube roots
