lessonSteps.description: Learn how to find the square root of a decimal number. The problem solved in this video is p^2 = 0.81.
lessonSteps.title: Square root of decimal

lessonSteps.description: Practice taking square roots of decimals and fractions.
lessonSteps.title: Roots of decimals & fractions

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations by squaring or finding square root of decimals and fractions.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with square roots: decimals & fractions

lessonSteps.description: When we know the volume of a cube, we can use the cube root of the volume to find the length of each side. We'll need to factor the volume and find 3 equal groups of factors. The value of one group is the length of one side of the cube.
lessonSteps.title: Dimensions of a cube from its volume

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving problems using your knowledge of square and cube roots.
lessonSteps.title: Square and cube challenge

lessonSteps.description: Review square roots, and try some practice problems.
lessonSteps.title: Square roots review

lessonSteps.description: Review cube roots, and try some practice problems.
lessonSteps.title: Cube roots review
Exponent properties with products
lessonSteps.description: To simplify expressions with exponents, there are a few properties that may help. One is that when two numbers with the same base are multiplied, the exponents can be added. Another is that when a number with an exponent is raised to another exponent, the exponents can be multiplied.

lessonSteps.title: Multiply powers
lessonSteps.description: Rewrite products of powers with the same base. For example, x²⋅x⁵ can be written as x⁷.

lessonSteps.title: Exponent properties with parentheses
lessonSteps.description: Learn two exponent properties: (ab)^c = (a^c)*(b^c) and (a^b)^c = a ^ (b*c). See WHY they work and HOW to use them. In other words, multiplying two numbers, then raising the product to an exponent is the same as raising each number to that exponent and then multiplying. Raising a number to an exponent and then to another exponent equals raising the base to the product of the two exponents.

lessonSteps.title: Powers of powers
lessonSteps.description: Rewrite powers of powers. For example, (x²)⁵ can be written as x¹⁰.

lessonSteps.title: Exponent properties with quotients
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

lessonSteps.title: Divide powers
lessonSteps.description: Rewrite quotients of powers with the same base. For example, (x⁵)/(x²) can be written as x³.

lessonSteps.title: Powers of products & quotients
lessonSteps.description: Rewrite powers of products and quotients. For example, (3⁵⋅x³)² can be written as 3¹⁰⋅x⁶.

lessonSteps.title: Exponent properties review
lessonSteps.description: Review the common properties of exponents that allow us to rewrite powers in different ways. For example, x²⋅x³ can be written as x⁵.

lessonSteps.title: Negative exponents
lessonSteps.description: Negative exponents can be rewritten in two ways. Firstly, start with 1 and divide it by 2 the same number of times as the exponent. Secondly, take the reciprocal of the base and raise it to the positive exponent.

lessonSteps.title: Negative exponent intuition
lessonSteps.description: How do negative exponents work? Let's build our intuition about why a^(-b) = 1/(a^b) and how this definition keeps exponent rules consistent. Continue the pattern of decreasing exponents by dividing by 'a', and see how it extends to zero and negative powers. While we're at it, we'll see why a^0 =1.

lessonSteps.title: Negative exponents
lessonSteps.description: Practice computing numbers raised to positive and negative exponents. Bases may be fractions.

lessonSteps.title: Negative exponents review
lessonSteps.description: Review the basics of negative exponents and try some practice problems.
For any base a and any integer exponents n and m, aⁿ⋅aᵐ=aⁿ⁺ᵐ. For any nonzero base, aⁿ/aᵐ=aⁿ⁻ᵐ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.
lessonSteps.title: Multiplying & dividing powers (integer exponents)

lessonSteps.description: Rewrite products or quotients of powers, including negative powers.
lessonSteps.title: Multiply & divide powers (integer exponents)

lessonSteps.description: For any integers a and b and for any exponents n, (a⋅b)ⁿ=aⁿ⋅bⁿ and (a/b)ⁿ=aⁿ/bⁿ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.
lessonSteps.title: Powers of products & quotients (integer exponents)

lessonSteps.description: Rewrite powers where the base includes more powers, and the exponents may be negative.
lessonSteps.title: Powers of products & quotients (integer exponents)

lessonSteps.description: Any non-zero number to the zero power equals one. Zero to any positive exponent equals zero. So, what happens when you have zero to the zero power?
lessonSteps.title: Powers of zero
Multiplying multiples of powers of 10
lessonSteps.description: Let's multiply (9 * 10^9) (-2 * 10^-3) using the power of exponents! Change the order of multiplication to make it easier, multiply the non-powers first. and then simplify the powers of 10. Remember, multiplying by a negative changes the sign of the product. It's all about using exponent properties to simplify the product.

lessonSteps.title: Multiplication and division with powers of ten
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving multiplication and division problems that involve powers of ten.

lessonSteps.title: Approximating with powers of 10
lessonSteps.description: How much larger was the world population than the US population in 2014? We can use division and powers of 10 to get a sense of just how many times as large the world population was. Is there really such a big difference between 10 to the 8th and 10 to the 9th? You bet there is!

lessonSteps.title: Approximating with powers of 10
lessonSteps.description: Practice comparing two real-world quantities by approximating them with powers of 10.

lessonSteps.title: Scientific notation example: 0.0000000003457
lessonSteps.description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very, very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!

lessonSteps.title: Scientific notation examples
lessonSteps.description: Scientific notation is a way of writing very large or very small numbers. A number is written in scientific notation when a number between 1 and 10 is multiplied by a power of 10. For example, 650,000,000 can be written in scientific notation as 6.5 ✕ 10^8. Created by Sal Khan and CK-12 Foundation.

lessonSteps.title: Scientific notation
lessonSteps.description: Practice expressing numbers in scientific notation.

lessonSteps.title: Scientific notation review
lessonSteps.description: Review the basics of scientific notation and try some practice problems.

lessons.title: Arithmetic with numbers in scientific notation

lessonSteps.description: In order to simplify multiplication and division using scientific notation, you should multiply and divide numbers with the same base, and add or subtract the exponents. Through this process, complex expressions can be simplified into a single value multiplied with 10 to a certain power. As an example, 7 times 10 to the fifth over 2 times 10 to the negative 2 times 2.5 times 10 to the ninth can be simplified to 1.4 times 10 to the negative 2. Scientific notation helps to simplify complex equations that involve multiplying and dividing numbers with the same base.
lessonSteps.title: Multiplying & dividing in scientific notation

lessonSteps.description: Multiplying really big or really small numbers is much easier when using scientific notation. When we multiply numbers in scientific notation, we can commute and associate the factors. That lets us multiply the decimal factors first. Then we can use exponent properties to multiply the powers of 10.
lessonSteps.title: Multiplying three numbers in scientific notation

lessonSteps.description: Practice expressing products and quotients in scientific notation.
lessonSteps.title: Multiplying & dividing in scientific notation

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to subtract numbers written in scientific notation. The problem solved in this video is (4.1 * 10^-2) - (2.6 * 10^-3).
lessonSteps.title: Subtracting in scientific notation

lessonSteps.description: Given two numbers in scientific notation, practice adding and subtracting them.
lessonSteps.title: Adding & subtracting in scientific notation

lessonSteps.description: Let's explore how to simplify expressions with numbers in scientific notation. We'll transform numbers into scientific notation, multiply and divide them, and then reassemble them. It's a cool and useful method for handling large or small numbers!
lessonSteps.title: Simplifying in scientific notation challenge
Scientific notation word problem: red blood cells
lessonSteps.description: Vampires and math students want to know: How many red blood cells are in the a human body? We can find the answer using scientific notation.

lessonSteps.title: Scientific notation word problem: U.S. national debt
lessonSteps.description: Ever wonder what your part of the national debt is? It might surprise you. What isn't surprising is that you can use scientific notation and division to figure out the answer.

lessonSteps.title: Scientific notation word problem: speed of light
lessonSteps.description: It is possible to simplify multiplication and division using scientific notation. This can be used to calculate the distance between the sun and the earth, which is 1.5 times 10 to the 11th power meters. This is an incredibly large distance and difficult to visualize. Scientific notation can be used to simplify calculations and understand large numbers. This involves using the commutative property to rearrange the numbers and multiplying the units, and then adding the exponents to simplify the equation.

lessonSteps.title: Scientific notation word problems
lessonSteps.description: Practice solving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division problems involving scientific notation.

units.title: Roots, exponents, & scientific notation
units.description: Understanding and solving exponents, radicals, and scientific notation without algebra.

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to solve the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2 with the variable on both sides. We start by visualizing the equation, then isolate the variable by performing the same operations on both sides. Finally, we solve the equation to find the value of the variable.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to equations with variables on both sides

lessonSteps.description: Solving equations like 20 - 7x = 6x - 6 with the variable on both sides involves a few steps! First, we add or subtract terms from both sides to separate constants and variables to different sides of the equation. Then, we simplify to isolate the variable. Finally, we check our answer by plugging it back into the original equation.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with variables on both sides: 20-7x=6x-6

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving one-variable equations like 20 - 7x = 6x - 6, where the variable appears on both sides of the equals sign.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with variables on both sides

lessonSteps.description: To solve the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4, we first eliminate fractions by multiplying both sides by the least common multiple of the denominators. Then, we add or subtract terms from both sides of the equation to group the x-terms on one side and the constants on the other. Finally, we solve and check as normal.
lessonSteps.title: Equation with variables on both sides: fractions

lessonSteps.description: Solve linear equations where the variable appears on both sides of the equation and the coefficients are decimals or fractions.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with variables on both sides: decimals & fractions

lessonSteps.description: The variable x is in the denominator in 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x. We can multiply both sides of the equation by x to turn it into a more familiar, linear form without fractions. From there, we isolate the variable to solve. P.S. x cannot equal zero, because then the equation would be undefined.
lessonSteps.title: Equation with the variable in the denominator

lessons.title: Equations with variables on both sides

lessonSteps.description: When an equation such as -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) has parentheses, we can distribute without changing the value of each side. Then combine like terms. Next, we move all the x-terms to one side and the constants to the other. Finally, we solve for x.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with parentheses

lessonSteps.description: Practice solving equations with parentheses using the distributive property.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with parentheses

lessonSteps.description: Solve linear equations that contain expressions with parentheses and the coefficients are rational numbers.
lessonSteps.title: Equations with parentheses: decimals & fractions

lessonSteps.description: To solve an equation we find the value of the variable that makes the equation true. For more complicated, fancier equations, this process can take several steps.
lessonSteps.title: Multi-step equations review
Number of solutions to equations
lessonSteps.description: A linear equation could have exactly 1, 0, or infinite solutions. If we can solve the equation and get something like x=b where b is a specific number, then we have one solution. If we end up with a statement that's always false, like 3=5, then there's no solution. If we end up with a statement that's always true, like 5=5, then there are infinite solutions.

lessonSteps.title: Worked example: number of solutions to equations
lessonSteps.description: Sal attempts to solve 8(3x + 10) = 28x - 14 - 4x only to find that the equation has no solution.

lessonSteps.title: Number of solutions to equations
lessonSteps.description: Practice telling whether an equation has one, zero, or infinite solutions. For example, how many solutions does the equation 8(3x+10)=28x-14-4x have?

lessonSteps.title: Creating an equation with no solutions
lessonSteps.description: Sal shows how to complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

lessonSteps.title: Creating an equation with infinitely many solutions
lessonSteps.description: Sal shows how to complete the equation 4(x - 2) + x = 5x + __ so that it has infinitely many solutions.

lessonSteps.title: Number of solutions to equations challenge
lessonSteps.description: Given a linear equation with missing values, determine appropriate values in order to have one, zero, or infinite solutions. For example, complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

lessonSteps.title: Sums of consecutive integers
lessonSteps.description: When solving a math problems involving consecutive integers, we can use algebra to set up an equation to solve for the smallest of the four integers.

lessonSteps.title: Sums of consecutive integers
lessonSteps.description: Practice finding the nth number in a sequence of consecutive numbers based on the sum.

lessonSteps.title: Sum of integers challenge
lessonSteps.description: The sum of three consecutive odd integers is 231. First let's identify the integers. If the smallest is x, what is the value of the next odd integer? Then we set up an equation, adding all three integers to get their total. We can solve for x, the smallest integer. Once we know the smallest, what is the largest integer?

Let's compare unit rates in equations and graphs. Learn how a change in 'x' affects 'y' in an equation like y = 6.5x, and see how this compares to the rate of change in a graph. Uncover why one might increase at a slower pace than the other.
lessonSteps.title: Rates & proportional relationships example

lessonSteps.description: Maria and Nadia calculate their speed on a road trip to Toronto using distance and time. We compare different speeds using equations and tables. Then, we reinforce the concept by comparing the revolution speeds of records.
lessonSteps.title: Rates & proportional relationships: gas mileage

lessonSteps.description: A variety of questions about rates and proportional relationships involving graphs, tables, and equations.
lessonSteps.title: Rates & proportional relationships

lessonSteps.description: In proportional relationships, the unit rate is the slope of the line. Changes in x lead to steady changes in y when there's a proportional relationship. We can use the unit rate to write and graph an equation of the line that represents the relationship.
lessonSteps.title: Graphing proportional relationships: unit rate

lessonSteps.description: Let's graph a proportional relationship from a table of values. The graph of a proportional relationship is a line, so we can graph from any 2 points in the table. The slope of the line represents the unit rate, so changes in x and y values determine the slope.
lessonSteps.title: Graphing proportional relationships from a table

lessonSteps.description: Let's graph the equation y = 2.5x. For every increase of 1 in x, y increases by 2.5. We call this the "unit rate" or "slope". The graph shows a proportional relationship because y changes at a constant rate as x changes and because y is 0 when x is 0.
lessonSteps.title: Graphing proportional relationships from an equation

lessonSteps.description: Practice graphing a line that represents a proportional relationship.
lessonSteps.title: Graphing proportional relationships

lessonSteps.description: Descartes created a system of two perpendicular axes (the x and y axes) which could be used to plot points in a plane. This enabled the visualization of algebraic equations in geometric form. For example, a linear equation like y = 2x + 1 could be plotted as a line on the coordinate plane, while a quadratic equation like y = x^2 could be plotted as a parabola. This linked algebra and geometry through the use of graphs.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to the coordinate plane

lessonSteps.description: The solution of an equation with one variable is a number. How does the solution of a 2-variable equation look like? Well, it is an ordered pair. Learn more about it and how to test solutions to 2-variable equations.
lessonSteps.title: Solutions to 2-variable equations

lessonSteps.description: How do you check if an ordered pair is a solution to a given equation? You need to plug in the numbers and see what equality results. Watch this video to see a worked example.
lessonSteps.title: Worked example: solutions to 2-variable equations

lessonSteps.description: Determine which ordered pairs are solutions to equations.
lessonSteps.title: Solutions to 2-variable equations

lessonSteps.description: Given a 2-variable equation and the x or y values of a solution, Sal finds the value of the other variable in the solution.
lessonSteps.title: Completing solutions to 2-variable equations

lessonSteps.description: Given the x or y value of a 2-variable equation solution, find the value for the other variable in the solution.
lessonSteps.title: Complete solutions to 2-variable equations

lessonSteps.description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are.  The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to intercepts

lessonSteps.description: Sal determines the x-intercept of a linear equation from a graph. Afterwards, he checks his work by plugging values back into the equation.
lessonSteps.title: x-intercept of a line

lessonSteps.description: Look at the graph of an equation to find x-intercepts and y-intercepts
lessonSteps.title: Intercepts from a graph

lessonSteps.description: Let's graph -5x + 4y = 20 from its intercepts. Intercepts are the places where a line crosses the x- and y-axes. When a line crosses the x-axis, the y value is 0. That's the x-intercept. When a line crosses the y-axis, the x value is 0. That's the y-intercept.  The line passes through those points.
lessonSteps.title: Intercepts from an equation

lessonSteps.description: Solve linear equations for the x-intercept and y-intercept
lessonSteps.title: Intercepts from an equation

lessonSteps.description: The y-intercept is the y-coordinate when x=0, and the x-intercept is the x-coordinate when y=0. The y-intercept is not in the table. Since the table represents a line, there's a constant rate of change of y with respect to x. So we can find that pattern and fill in skipped values from the table to find the y-intercept.
lessonSteps.title: Intercepts from a table

lessonSteps.description: Let's find the x- and y-intercepts of the equation 2y + 1/3x = 12, where a line crosses the x-axis (the x-intercept) and the y-axis (the y-intercept) on a graph. To find the x-intercept, we make y equal to 0 and solve the equation for x. To find the y-intercept, we make x equal to 0 and solve for y.
lessonSteps.title: Worked example: intercepts from an equation

lessonSteps.description: The x-intercept is where a line crosses the x-axis, and the y-intercept is the point where the line crosses the y-axis. Thinking about intercepts helps us graph linear equations.
lessonSteps.title: Intercepts of lines review (x-intercepts and y-intercepts)

lessonSteps.description: Slope tells us how steep a line is. It's like measuring how quickly a hill goes up or down. We find the slope by seeing how much we go up or down (vertical change) for each step to the right (horizontal change). If a line goes up 2 steps for every 1 step to the right, its slope is 2.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to slope

lessonSteps.description: Walk through a graphical explanation of how to find the slope from two points and what it means.
lessonSteps.title: Intro to slope

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to write the slope formula from scratch and how to apply it to find the slope of a line from two points.
lessonSteps.title: Slope formula

lessonSteps.description: A line that's flat has a slope of 0. If a line goes up as you move to the right, it has a positive slope. The steeper it is, the bigger the slope. If a line goes down as you move to the right, it has a negative slope. The steeper it is, the more negative the slope.
lessonSteps.title: Slope & direction of a line

lessonSteps.description: Sal analyzes what it means for a slope to be positive or negative (spoiler: it affects the direction of the line!)
lessonSteps.title: Positive & negative slope

lessonSteps.description: The slope of a line is rise over run. Learn how to calculate the slope of the line in a graph by finding the change in y and the change in x.
lessonSteps.title: Worked example: slope from graph

lessonSteps.description: Find the slope of a line on the coordinate plane.
lessonSteps.title: Slope from graph

lessonSteps.description: Slope is like a hill's steepness. We find it by dividing the vertical change (rise) by the horizontal change (run). If we move right on a graph and go up, the slope is positive. If we go down, it's negative. We can find the slope between any two points on a line, and it's always the same.
lessonSteps.title: Slope of a line: negative slope

lessonSteps.description: Let's find the slope of the line that goes through the ordered pairs (4,2) and (-3, 16). The slope, or steepness, of a line is found by dividing the vertical change (rise) by the horizontal change (run). The formula is slope =(y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁), where (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) are the coordinates of two points on the line.
lessonSteps.title: Worked example: slope from two points

lessonSteps.description: Find the slope of the line that goes through the two points that are given to you.
lessonSteps.title: Slope from two points

lessonSteps.description: Worked examples of finding the slope of a line given its equation, using many forms of equations.
lessonSteps.title: Slope from equation

lessonSteps.description: Learn to convert equations like 4x + 2y = -8 into slope-intercept form.
lessonSteps.title: Converting to slope-intercept form

lessonSteps.description: Find the slopes of lines whose equations are given in various forms. For example, find the slope of 2x+3y=5.
lessonSteps.title: Slope from equation

lessonSteps.description: When two points have the same y-value, it means they lie on a horizontal line. The slope of such a line is 0, and you will also find this by using the slope formula.
lessonSteps.title: Slope of a horizontal line

lessonSteps.description: The slope of a line is a measure of its steepness. Mathematically, slope is calculated as "rise over run" (change in y divided by change in x).
lessonSteps.title: Slope review
Intro to slope-intercept form
lessonSteps.description: Slope-intercept form (y=mx+b) of linear equations highlights the slope (m) and the y-intercept (b) of a line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

lessonSteps.title: Intro to slope-intercept form
lessonSteps.description: Learn about the slope-intercept form of two-variable linear equations, and how to interpret it to find the slope and y-intercept of their line.

lessonSteps.title: Worked examples: slope-intercept intro
lessonSteps.description: Worked examples practicing the relationship between slope, y-intercept, and linear equation in slope-intercept form.

lessonSteps.title: Slope-intercept intro
lessonSteps.description: Practice your basic understanding of slope-intercept form for linear equations.

lessonSteps.title: Graph from slope-intercept equation
lessonSteps.description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.

lessonSteps.title: Graphing slope-intercept form
lessonSteps.description: Learn how to graph lines whose equations are given in the slope-intercept form y=mx+b.

lessonSteps.title: Graph from slope-intercept form
lessonSteps.description: Practice drawing the graph of a line given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y = 3x + 2.

lessonSteps.title: Graphing lines from slope-intercept form review
lessonSteps.description: Slope intercept form is y=mx+b, where m is slope and b is the y-intercept. We can use this form of a linear equation to draw the graph of that equation on the x-y coordinate plane.
Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.
lessonSteps.title: Slope-intercept equation from graph

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to find the slope-intercept equation of a line from two points on that line.
lessonSteps.title: Writing slope-intercept equations

lessonSteps.description: Practice finding the slope-intercept equation of a line from its graph.
lessonSteps.title: Slope-intercept equation from graph

lessonSteps.description: Learn how to write an equation in slope-intercept form (y=mx+b) for the line with a slope of -3/4 that goes through the point (0,8). We identify the slope (m) and y-intercept (b) to create our equation y = (-3/4)*x + 8.
lessonSteps.title: Slope-intercept equation from slope & point

lessonSteps.description: Given two points on a line, we can write an equation for that line by finding the slope between those points, then solving for the y-intercept in the slope-intercept equation y=mx+b. In this example, we write an equation of the line that passes through the points (-1,6) and (5,-4).

lessonSteps.description: When solving systems of linear equations, one method is to graph both equations on the same coordinate plane. The intersection of the two lines represents a solution that satisfies both equations. Other, more mathematical, methods may also be used.

When solving a system of equations using substitution, you can isolate one variable and substitute it with an expression from another equation. This will allow you to solve for one variable, which you can then use to solve for the other.
